column2: In a magocracy, aptitude with the great Art of magic is seen as the primary qualification for rulership.
Arcane spellcasters are the majority of the electors, and those with great arcane talents are favoured for election.
In a few rare societies, warlocks detain political power and allow only one of their number to rule.
In some religious orders, monks are the dominant group and the wielders of political power.
In a commonwealth, all free people can vote, in principle. In practice, this power is often wielded for them by professional politicians.
All free citizens are voters, but in practice their votes are readily bought by politicians. Those who control cities have great electoral sway.
Under Divine Mandate, the favour of the gods determines the right to rule. Those who carry the blood of the gods, or are blessed by them with power, will go far.
Divine casters wield the most electoral power, as they are seen as the best judges of the gods' blessing.

[Root.GetFirstName] is a servant of the gods

The Ordning is the strict code of honor, religion, and culture that permeates all true giant societies. Those low on the Ordning are expected to obey those above them, even so far as different breeds of giant.

An ophidian cabal is a loose term grouping the diverse and insidious serpent kingdoms ruled by the Yuan-Ti, Naga or, more rarely, the Sarrukh. Unified by their caste system, the closer an individual is to the ideal snake form, the higher in rank and power they are.
In the wildlands of Faerûn, scale-skinned warriors live in loose tribal societies usually controlled by the strongest or most cunning amongst them.

Monastic Feudal is the broad term for the governments of Toril that center around churches and temples, but maintains military power with feudal barons. This government is typically held by Halflings or Kara-Turans of the Padhran faith. Distinct from Divine governments, which are often led by Clerics and Paladins, Monastic Feudal rules through joint harmony between temporal and spiritual rulers.

When a Sahuagin lord perishes, whether by battle or disease, it creates a nasty legal issue. Normal advancement of rank is done through ritual combat. However since the would-be defender is dead, the leading warriors must decide amongst themselves who is the strongest. Blood ties means little, only in how well you can spill it.
The Magister is chosen seemingly semi-randomly by Mystra herself, often from among those talented in the Art who happen to be physically close to the dying Magister.
The leadership of Toril's gold dragons is in principle decided on merit, but in practice by a combination of prestige and influence, mediated through complex ties of friendship and mutual knowledge.
